posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Is this not the purpose of the interruptability of commands?

The end(bool) method accepts a boolean true if the command was interrupted or false if it ended at the expected time (i.e. isFinished() returned true).  You can handle your graceful cleanup in there as that method should run before the command interrupting it starts.

As far as I’m aware, commands don’t get queued up, so if you have a command running that requires subsystem X, and you trigger a different one with the same requirement, then the first will be interrupted and allow the 2nd to take over.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
Don’t do this. end is a lifecycle function meant to be called a) in a specific order and b) exclusively by the command scheduler.

To the OP:

Commands can be cancelled manually by calling command.cancel() , which will tell the scheduler to cancel the command (and run the appropriate lifecycle methods). They will also be cancelled if they are interrupted by another command requiring the same subsystem. For example, if you have a command running that requires the Intake subsystem, and another Command is scheduled (ie, via a button press) that also requires that subsystem, the first command will be cancelled before the second starts running. There is no need or way for commands to “relinquish” control of the subsystem- the command will simply stop being called.

posts.name: brandon herr
posts.cooked: oh i see thanks for the tip i had no idea

Also, you can bind commands to buttons in different ways: for example, whileTrue (instead of onTrue ) will schedule the command when the button is pressed and cancel it when the button is released. The command-based framework has a lot of functionality; I recommend reading the docs.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: You’re thinking of until , not end .
